case_vignette: A 5-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of the rash shown in Figure A. The parents report that their child had an episode of pharyngitis one week ago. The child reports feeling nauseated recently and says his knees have been bothering him. Past medical history is insignificant. A stool sample is positive for occult blood.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I have a rash, I've been feeling sick to my stomach, and my knees are bothering me.
Have you had any joint pain or stiffness in other parts of your body?
No, just my knees have been bothering me.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your knees?
No, I haven't had any injuries or trauma to my knees.
Have you had any recent changes in your weight or diet?
No, there haven't been any changes in my weight or diet.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to new environments?
No, I haven't had any recent travel or been exposed to new environments.
Have you had any recent stressful events or changes in your life?
No, I haven't had any stressful events or changes in my life recently.

My past medical history is not significant for anything like that.
Have you been taking any medications recently?
No, I haven't been taking any medications recently.
Have you had any recent blood tests or laboratory work done?
Yes, I had a stool sample tested and it was positive for occult blood.
Final Diagnosis: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
